bibl.title: Letter from Ralph Cooper Hutchison to Philip Showalter Hench, November 25, 1941

div1.p: Hutchison reports on his mother-in-law's ill health and requests an autographed reprint of his yellow fever article for Culley. Hutchison admires the Cornwell painting.

div1.head: Letter from Ralph Cooper Hutchison to Philip Showalter Hench, November 25, 1941

opener.dateline:
THE PRESIDENT'S OFFICE
WASHINGTON AND JEFFERSON COLLEGE
WASHINGTON, PENNSYLVANIA
November 25, 1941

div1.p:
The thrombosis is coronary. Mrs. Willets
is still living, but the recurring sinking spells
would indicate that there is very little chance for
her recovery. I will let you know if she goes so
that you can drop a note to Harriet. Meanwhile,
Harriet's address is 601 South Adams Street, Glendale,
California.

I am eager to hear of your part in the
Cornwell painting. I think it is a fine piece of
work, and am planning for the right time to present
this picture to the student body before taking it
over to the Chemistry Building.

Mrs. Culley, formerly Miss Hough, who
has been deeply interested in what you have achieved
on this yellow fever investigation, would like very much
to have one of these reprints autographed by yourself.
I mean the one entitled “Conquerors of Yellow Fever.”

Thanks for telling me when you will be there
and when you will be away. I will make it now as soon
as I get into shape.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, Hutch Doctor Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
RCH/M
